description: APPLICATION FOR PLANNING CONSENT FOR THE ERECTION OF A REAR EXTENSION AT FIRST FLOOR LEVEL AND A REAR ROOF EXTENSION
decision_conditions: Reason : 1 - The proposal, by reason of inconsistent measurements on plans, elevations, and site location plans, fails to demonstrate it has provided drawings and information necessary to accurately describe the development, as required by Article 7(1)(c)(ii) of the Development Management Procedure Order 2015.

Reason : 2 - The proposed rear dormer and two storey rear extension, by reason of their combined siting and design would result in a prominent, visually intrusive, incongruous and unsympathetic form of development along the rear building line to the detriment of the visual amenity of the host property, and the surrounding area in general. The scheme would be contrary to the London Plan design policies D1, D4, SPP Policies DMD2 and DMD3, and Merton Core Strategy 2011 policy CS 14

Reason : 3 - The proposed rear dormer and two storey rear extension, by reason of their combined siting, design, depth and height would result in a visually intrusive and overbearing form of development to nos. 165 and 169 St Heliers Avenue and in addition, overshadowing to no. 165 St Heliers Avenue. The scheme is contrary to the SPP 2014 policies DM D2, DM D3.

Reason : 4 - INFORMATIVE
Note to Applicant
In accordance with paragraph 38 of the NPPF, The London Borough of Merton  (LBM) takes a positive and proactive approach to development proposals focused on solutions. LBM works with applicants/agents in a positive and proactive manner by:
"	Offering a pre-application advice and duty desk service. 
"	Where possible, suggesting solutions to secure a successful outcome.
"	As appropriate, updating applicants/agents of any issues that may arise in the processing of their application.
In this instance:
"	The application was not considered to comply with the provisions of the Development Plan and NPPF as submitted, and would have required substantial changes such that a new application would be required. 
"	The application was considered to be fundamentally contrary to the provisions of the Development Plan and the NPPF, and there were not considered to be any solutions to resolve this conflict. 
"	It is noted that the applicant/agent did not engage in any pre-application discussions.
"	The applicant is advised to seek pre-application advice on any resubmission.
